newsitem.title: CYPRUS: Turk Cypriot far-rightists to invade ghost town.
newsitem.headline: Turk Cypriot far-rightists to invade ghost town.

text.p: Turkish Cypriot ultra-nationalist leader Mehmet Arslan at the weekend called on followers to enter the empty Greek Cypriot town of Varosha and lay claim to houses there.
He told a rally late on Saturday at the fence surrounding the abandoned town that a march would be held on March 2, finishing in a mass entry of Varosha.
"We do not believe any of the authorities will stop us...Anyone who likes any of the houses there should spray their name on it, that house will then be theirs," Arslan said.
"I wholeheartedly support this march," said Kenan Akin, the Turkish Cypriot "minister of agriculture and forests" who attended the meeting.

The island has been divided since 1974 when Turkish forces invaded after Greek Cypriots staged a coup backed by the military regime then ruling Greece. Negotiations to unite the two communities in federation have stalled.
Turkish Cypriot leader, Rauf Denktas, two weeks ago said people would not be settled in Varosha unless Greek Cypriots went ahead with plans to buy anti-aircraft missiles from Russia.
Denktas heads a breakaway state in the Turkish dominated north of the island, recognised only by Ankara.

Varosha, called Maras in Turkish Cypriot, was a seaside resort town before Turkey invaded northern Cyprus in 1974. Its Greek Cypriot population moved south but Turkish Cypriots who seized the area did not move into the town.
Tension between the two communities has risen with the decision to buy the missiles which was approved by parliament two weeks ago.

Four Greek Cypriot civilians and one Turkish soldier have been killed on the island in recent months. One Greek Cypriot was beaten to death by Turkish Cypriot ultra-nationalists after crossing into Turkish controlled territory.
